Dorinda is flown from her bowers,</br>The city has call'd her away,</br>Now heavily pass the soft hours,</br>Her presence could render so gay.
The country around seems to mourn,</br>The buds are afraid to appear,</br>So rough the sweet season is grown,</br>The pleasantest once of the year.
She's gone — and rude Boreas blows,</br>Instead of the zephyrus breeze,</br>Now troubled the rivulet flows,</br>To water her favourite trees.
The roses for sorrow will fade,</br>The vi'lets to blossom forbear,</br>And her flocks they will stray from the glade,</br>Since Doris no longer is here.
The bower she planted with care,</br>The woodbines she taught to entwine,</br>Forget their fresh blossoms to wear,</br>Since she can her bower resign.
The linnet renouncing her song,</br>Deserts for her sake the sweet vale,</br>No more bound the lambkins along,</br>But bleating their mistress bewail.
The thrush and the blackbird have chose,</br>For their fondest some sad moving notes,</br>No longer they perch on the rose,</br>Nor thro' air their bold music floats.
Each Shepherd attunes his soft lay,</br>The praise of Dorinda to sing,</br>Her flocks frisk about them and play,</br>And listen around in a string.
One says she is mild as the morn,</br>And sweet as the dew on the bud,</br>That nature she's form'd to adorn,</br>So gentle, so fair, and so good.
Another with energy tells,</br>She would weep for the death of a hare,</br>In her breast so much gentleness dwells,</br>That even an insect she'd spare.
A third gladly catches the tale,</br>And avers he has seen her with speed,</br>Hastening along thro' the vale,</br>To shun a poor kid that must bleed.
Old Strephon thus leans on his spade,</br>And crossing his arms on his breast,</br>He swears by the hill, grove and mead,</br>He would try to out do all the rest.
What he said I cannot disclose,</br>Dorinda might take it amiss,</br>To flatter would hurt her repose,</br>It never could add to her bliss.
Return, gentle Doris, return,</br>And with thee dear maid bring along,</br>New joy to the vallies that mourn,</br>And strength to the villagers song.
Then each northern blast shall away,</br>And zephyrs return to the grove,</br>The linnet will sing from her spray;</br>And warble a sonnet of love.
The vi'let shall hasten to blow,</br>And cowslips again gild the plain,</br>The rose all its beauties will shew,</br>To welcome her home to the green.
Her bower again shall look gay,</br>And woodbines embrace it around,</br>At her foot the young lambkins will play,</br>With many a frolicking bound.
The stream will glide smoothly adown,</br>The descent of yon grassy field,</br>Oh, are there such pleasures in town,</br>As that very meadow can yield.
The murmuring zephyrs their hope,</br>Breathe softly to each budding tree,</br>She will come — she will stray down the slope—</br>They whisper with pleasure and glee.
O how the white hyacinth longs,</br>In triumph to sit next her breast,</br>The goldfinch prepares with her songs,</br>To charm her sweet mistress to rest.
'Tis the soft voice of friendship that calls,</br>And sweetly invites to thy home,</br>O come to these ivy-bound walls,</br>Too long my Dorinda you roam.
The vale she was form'd to adorn,</br>Her absence all pleasure destroys,</br>Return, gentle Doris, return,</br>Thy absence is death to our joys.</br>
